conclusion: Liquid will flow out from A, B, C, and D and needs to be predicted which container (E, F, G, or H) it will flow into after passing through baffles.
The image shows four colored inlet blocks (A, B, C, D) at the top, angled baffles in the middle, and four colored chutes (E, F, G, H) at the bottom.
Each inlet block (A, B, C, D) has a distinct color: green, yellow, orange, and pink respectively.
The angled baffles are colored and positioned to guide the flow of liquid downward and sideways.
The chutes at the bottom (E, F, G, H) are colored green, white, blue, and pink respectively.
Each colored inlet block (A, B, C, D) has the same color as the first baffle it will strike.
The angled baffles act like mirrors, reflecting the flow downward and sideways until it reaches a matching-colored chute at the bottom.
Tracking the color-matching path of every bounce shows that each starting color ultimately lands in the chute of the identical color at the base.
Liquid from A flows into container E.
Liquid from B flows into container F.
Liquid from C flows into container G.
Liquid from D flows into container H.
